head.title: Optical Realization of Quantum Gambling Machine

article.h1: Optical Realization of Quantum Gambling Machine

span.span: Yong-Sheng Zhang, Chuan-Feng Li, Wan-Li Li, Yun-Feng Huang, and Guang-Can Guo

div.p: Quantum gambling â€” a secure remote two-party protocol which has no classical counterpart â€” is demonstrated through optical approach. A photon is prepared by Alice in a superposition state of two potential paths. Then one path leads to Bob and is split into two parts. The security is confirmed by quantum interference between Aliceâ€™s path and one part of Bobâ€™s path. It is shown that a practical quantum gambling machine can be feasible by this way.

As a kind of game, gambling plays an important role in the society and nature which are full of conflict, competition and cooperation. Up to now, game theory has been investigated with mathematical methods [1] and applied to study economy, psychology, ecology, biology and many other fields [2, 3].

One might wonder why games like gambling can have anything to do with quantum physics. After all, game theory is about numbers that entities are efficiently acting to maximize or minimize. However, if linear superpositions of the actions are permitted, games will be generalized into quantum domain [4, 5]. Quantizing games may be interesting in several fields [4], such as foundation of game theory, games of survival and quantum communication [6]. Moreover, quantum mechanics may assure the fairness in remote gambling [7].
In this letter, we present a quantum gambling machine composed of optical elements.

We may firstly investigate the simplest classical gambling machine: one particle and two boxes Ağ´italic-AA and Bğµitalic-BB. During a game, the casino (Alice) stores the particle in Ağ´italic-AA or Bğµitalic-BB randomly, then the player (Bob) guesses which box the particle is in. For the two parties do not trust each other, even a third party, a remote classical gambling is impossible. If Bob finds the particle in box Bğµitalic-BB (state |bâŸ©ketğ‘VERTBAR:| italic-b CLOSE:rangle\left|b\right\rangle), he wins one coin, otherwise he loses the bet. Obviously, the probability for Bob to win is exactly 50%percent50NUMBER:50 POSTFIX:percent50\%. In the experiment, a linear-polarized photon is employed as the particle. A single game of gambling with this machine is described as follows. After Bob put in his bet â€” one coin, the machine will inform Alice and Bob to select the parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon (adjusting HWP ağ‘italic-aa) and Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta (adjusting HWP b1subscriptğ‘1italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1} and b2subscriptğ‘2italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{2} simultaneously). Then a photon is generated from the polarizer and distributed to three parts. If the detector D1subscriptğ·1italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{1} or D3subscriptğ·3italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{3} responds, Bob win one or Rğ‘…italic-RR coins; if D2subscriptğ·2italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endD_{2} responds, Bob loses the bet (then the bet will be conserved for Alice automatically).

Optical approach has many advantages. By making use of two different freedom degrees of the photon (location and polarization), an optical quantum gambling machine may be realized conveniently with several HWPs, PBSes and detectors. Particularly, the decoherence of all-optical system is relatively low [9], while the protocol is very sensitive to the errors caused by the device and environment. As discussed by Goldenberg et al. [7], for a successful realization of quantum gambling, the error rate has to be lower than 2/R32superscriptğ‘…3italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end\sqrt{2/R^{3}}. Since the error rate in the experiment is only about 140140FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:40 ARG:end\frac{1}{40}, a practical quantum gambling may be carried out with this optical machine under the condition R<14.4ğ‘…14.4italic-R RELOP:less-than NUMBER:14.4R<14.4.

Our experiment has shown that quantum gambling and quantum games have real physical counterpart, and a practical quantum gambling machine can be realized with simple optical devices. It can be expected that quantum mechanics may bring other interesting results in game theory.
